author: Rick Bella | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Most Clackamas County property owners will see property taxes rise 3 percent this year -- again
text:
Assessor Bob Vroman Most Clackamas County property owners can expect this year's property tax bill to increase by 3 percent over last year's, along with a similar increase in assessed value, said Clackamas County Assessor Bob Vroman .
However, Vroman says bigger increases may be coming for property owners where voters have new approved bonds or levies or the various taxing districts must collect more revenue to pay off existing debts. The result is a hodge-podge that makes blanket statements useless.
Clackamas County town hall meetings Oct. 27: 2 to 3 p.m., Gladstone Senior Center, 1050 Portland Ave. Oct. 27: 7 to 8:30 p.m., Damascus Community Church, 14251 S.E. Rust Way Oct. 28: 9 to 10:30 a.m., The Milwaukie Center, 5440 S.E. Kellogg Creek Drive Oct. 29: 2 to 3:30 p.m., Lake Oswego Adult Community Center, 505 G Ave. Nov. 2: 7 to 8:30 p.m., Development Services Building, 150 Beavercreek Road, Oregon City Nov. 4: 7 to 8:30 p.m., The Milwaukie Center, 5440 S.E. Kellogg Creek Drive Nov. 5: 12:30 to 2 p.m., Sandy Community & Senior Center, 38348 Pioneer Blvd. Nov. 5: 7 to 8:30 p.m., Estacada Community Center, 200 S.W. Club House Drive For questions, call 503-655-8671. -- Rick Bella "In Clackamas County, we have 17 cities, 18 school districts and 14 fire districts that give us about 350 areas with unique taxing situations," Vroman said. "Real estate is local, local, local – and so are the taxes. This makes the tax story in Clackamas County very hard to tell simply."
To help taxpayers understand their bills, Vroman is holding eight town hall meetings around the county.
Vroman said some of the biggest increases in tax bills will be seen east of Newberg, where an 8 percent increase will go to the Newberg School District to pay off existing debt. Colton property owners will see a 7.5 percent increase because Colton School District voters approved a new bond issue.
Property owners in the North Clackamas School District overall will see a 6.25 percent to pay off existing debt. This, in turn, will fuel a 5.75 percent in Happy Valley area and a 5.5 percent increase in Milwaukie – both in the school district.
The total of taxes the county will collect for all cities and districts will be $725 million, and increase of nearly 6 percent over last year's total of $684 million. But Vroman cautions that tax-limitation measures passed by Oregon voters cloud the picture for property owners looking for direct connections between real market values and their tax bills.
Vroman and his staff will also embark on their annual series of town halls from Oct. 27 to Nov. 5. They will hold eight meetings around the county to provide information and answer questions.
"I know the tax picture can seem confusing," Vroman said. "I hope people with questions will come out so we can help them."
